location.physicalLocation: British Library: India Office Records and Private Papers

titleInfo.title: Letter No. 39 of 1850 from Lieutenant-Colonel Samuel Hennell, Resident in the Persian Gulf, to Arthur Malet, Chief Secretary to the Government Bombay

mods.abstract: In the letter Samuel Hennell writes that he has written to Sheikh Sultan ben Suggar [Sulṭān bin Saqr Āl Qāsimī], protesting at his involvement in the African slave trade. The movements of vessels suspected of being used in the slave trade are being monitored by the British Government's Native Agent at Sharjah, Moollah Houssein [Mullā Husayn]. Hennell includes an English translation of a letter from Sultan ben Suggar, dated 17 December 1849, in which the Sheikh says that he has punished those of his subjects that Hennell (writing in an earlier letter) claimed were importing slaves from Zanzibar and Berbera.
